summary: Avengers: Endgame And Game Of Thrones Win The Top Prizes At The 2019 MTV Movie And TV Awards
title: Avengers: Endgame And Game Of Thrones Win The Top Prizes At The 2019 MTV Movie And TV Awards
body:
Avengers: Endgame And Game Of Thrones Win The Top Prizes At The 2019 MTV Movie And TV Awards

Credit: MTV

MTV’s biggest night happened this week as the network revealed who the winners of the 2019 MTV Movie & TV awards were at last. The fans had their say as the winners of this particular awards show comes from online voting from the general public.

The kudocast was pre-taped over the weekend with Zachary Levi as its host of the evening. Many pop culture favorites were honored with the…

summary: Alice Through the Looking Glass (JAMES BOBIN, 2016) did time travel better than Avengers: Endgame (JOE & ANTHONY RUSSO, 2019).
body:
Alice Through the Looking Glass (JAMES BOBIN, 2016) did time travel better than Avengers: Endgame (JOE & ANTHONY RUSSO, 2019).

You can’t change my mind.

summary: Fanboy News Network Episode 72 - Fanboy News Network
title: Fanboy News Network Episode 72 - Fanboy News Network
excerpt: “Gone with the Wind part 2” The boys talk about having seen Avengers: Endgame and a lot of the details surrounding it. Jeff talks about the movies We have always lived in the Castle and John Wick 3 Daniel talks … Continue reading →
description:
Fanboy News Network Episode 72

“Gone with the Wind part 2”

The boys talk about having seen Avengers: Endgame and a lot of the details surrounding it.

Jeff talks about the movies We have always lived in the Castle and John Wick 3

Daniel talks about wanting to see Shadow, the follow up to Hero.

The end of Game of Thrones.

Why we are tired of all the petitions.

A shout out to the cameo episode of What we do in the Shadows.

Daniel finally catches The Umbrella Academy.

Just discovered the Wrestling Community on Twitch.

What the boys are reading.

summary: Il Marvel Cinematic Universe continua a segnare la storia del cinema
title: Il Marvel Cinematic Universe continua a segnare la storia del cinema
body:
Going News | 18 giugno 2019 | cinema, TV | di Alessandra Bormio | Riproduzione riservata

Avengers: Endgame e Captain Marvel hanno ottenuto riconoscimenti anche nel corso degli MTV Movie & TV Awards 2019

[Disney]


Il Marvel Cinematic Universe ha caratterizzato gli MTV Movie & TV Awards 2019, un risultato conseguito grazie ai popolari Avengers: Endgame e Captain Marvel che rispettivamente hanno racimolato quattro confezioni di popcorn dorate.


Avengers: Endgame ha vinto nella categoria riservata al miglior film, mentre Robert Downey Jr. e Josh Brolin hanno vinto rispettivamente il Best Hero e il Best Villain. Captain Marvel ha ottenuto il Best Fight, per il confronto fisico tra Brie Larson e Minn-Erva di Gemma Chan.


Più riconoscimenti hanno ottenuto anche i film A Star Is Born e Tutte le volte che ho scritto ti amo, distribuito da Netflix. La serie televisiva Il Trono di Spade si è assicurata il titolo di Best Show.


Ecco l'elenco dei premi e dei rispettivi destinatari:

Best Movie
Avengers: Endgame

Best Show
Game of Thrones

Best Performance in a Movie
Lady Gaga (Ally) in A Star Is Born

Best Performance in a Show
Elisabeth Moss (June Osborne/Offred) in The Handmaid’s Tale

Best Hero
Robert Downey Jr. (Tony Stark / Iron Man) in Avengers: Endgame

Best Villain
Josh Brolin (Thanos) in Avengers: Endgame

Best Kiss
Noah Centineo (Peter Kavinsky) & Lana Condor (Lara Jean) in Tutte le volte che ho scritto ti amo

Reality Royalty
Love & Hip Hop: Atlanta

Best Comedic Performance
Dan Levy (David Rose) in Schitt’s Creek

Breakthrough Performance
Noah Centineo (Peter Kavinsky) in Tutte le volte che ho scritto ti amo

Best Fight
Captain Marvel vs. Minn-Erva in Captain Marvel

Best Real-Life Hero
Ruth Bader Ginsburg in RBG

Most Frightened Performance
Sandra Bullock (Malorie) in Bird Box

Best Documentary
Surviving R. Kelly

Best Host
Nick Cannon in Wild ‘n Out

Most Meme-able Moment
Colton Underwood jumps the fence in The Bachelor

Best Musical Moment
Shallow in A Star Is Born

blog.name: fantheorist-sophaloaf
blog.title: Fan Theorist
blog.description: Theories about everything from superheroes to cartoons!

summary: The Difference Between Infinity War and Endgame
title: The Difference Between Infinity War and Endgame
body:
OH GOD SORRY! SPOILER ALERT!

Hello all my fellow Fan Theorists! Apologies for that major spoiler there. If that hadn’t cued you in, though, this whole post is gonna be riddled with spoilers for Endgame and, yes, Infinity War, too, so if you haven’t seen them, duck out of this post now. (Just a really quick tid-bit: do y’all remember when we thought that everyone who died was in the soul world? Oops.)

So, let’s talk about Infinity War and Endgame, the unofficial two part Avengers movie, both of which were equally devastating, maybe even more so for Endgame because Tony isn’t coming back, at least not as RDJ. With that gut punch out of the way, let’s get into it. Infinity War and Endgame both have very different feels from one another, as if they’d both been directed by two different people. From what I’ve seen of the Russos’ work, in this franchise at least, they tend to have that serious, realistic vibe to their movies in a way that DC comics utterly fails with theirs. I mean, Civil War, while not being my favorite movie in the franchise, was a really fantastic movie and did the “gritty realism” tone very well. They also produced one of the most well-loved Marvel movies of all time, Captain America: The Winter Soldier, which genuinely made Marvel movies what we know they are today. And in that vein, I think that Infinity War feels a lot like those movies, but Endgame? Nope. It has a dark, depressing tone about it, as if the whole thing, beginning to end, is just one long funeral, and I think that was the point, cause it kinda was. I mean, half of the characters, including the most beloved Marvel character of all time (Spidey), were dead, including fan favorites, like Black Panther, Loki, and all of the Guardians.

But probably the biggest difference between the two was Thanos. He felt like a genuinely different person. Gone was the somewhat sympathetic, yet still very evil deflated plum, replaced by an egotistical psychopath with a god complex. And the differences aren’t even subtle. So what happened? Well, the reason that I think Infinity War and Endgame are so different was because the two of them were set through two different perspectives. In Endgame, it was pretty clear that Tony was the protagonist, but in Infinity War, it isn’t very clear. The plot is scattered throughout three different big settings, on Titan, in Wakanda, and on Vormir, each scene having a different tone and feel to them. For example, Titan had a “sunset” vibe, as if the sun was setting on everyone’s time there on Titan, indicating that, no, they would not win there. Wakanda had a “new day” sort of vibe, and seeing as it was the last stop on Thanos’ list, we figured that it would be the location that the Avengers would win the battle, and if they weren’t planning on pulling the rug out from under us, we’d have been right. And Vormir is special because it has this magical, mystical vibe, as if it is taking place within Twilight, which makes sense since it is a magical, mystical place. And despite all of that, there is still one constant in the plot, one character that connects everything together: Thanos. *cue the gasps*

Yes, you heard me correctly, Thanos, the big, ugly grape dude who killed off Peter Parker, is Infinity War’s protagonist. Now, don’t get me wrong here, he’s not the hero, he’s not even a good guy, and protagonist doesn’t have to mean “hero,” it just has be the person around which the story is centered, and the story is unabashedly centered around Thanos. Don’t believe me?

Yeah, remember this? Historically, they have only ever, ever done this for the main protagonist(s) of the film. Iron Man? Iron Man will return. Captain America? Captain America will return. The Avengers? The Avengers will return. Every time without fail they have put the protagonists and only the protagonists in that slot there. So, where does that leave us? Well, it explains why the two movies were so distinctly different. Each major scene’s tone was reflected through his eyes. Vormir? A beautiful and slightly mystical atmosphere with a somber tone, because Gamora is dead but he is collecting the Soul Stone. Titan? The sun setting on the time that half the universe has. Wakanda? A bright, sunny atmosphere where literally nothing could possibly go wrong with his plan and no one can stand in his way. That’s why we get that weird Gamora in the soul stone flash back and why we see him sitting on his farm in the final scene as the sun rises on a new era of his making. It is a beautiful, spectacular movie and I cannot stress that enough, even if the protagonist is a rotten prune and half of the universe dies, and this symbolism is a huge part of why that is.

So now, let’s talk about Endgame Thanos. He is cold, evil, and nothing like his Infinity War self, but honestly, is that a big shock to anyone? I mean, in literally every other movie, he has been an evil, dangerous tyrant, then he shows up in Infinity War as a misunderstood bad boy and everyone just… accepts it? No, no, no, no. What we have here is a case of there-are-two-sides-to-every-story-itis. Thanos is a power-hungry dictator who wants death and destruction and his actions in Infinity War, killing off innocent people and killing anyone who gets in his way, or attempting to, but we just think that it is flawed story telling because we don’t realize that it is all being told from inside of Thanos’ twisted mind. Endgame Thanos is the true Thanos. The gross raisin of death who throws a tantrum when he doesn’t get his way and wants to play with people’s lives like they’re dolls, that is who he really is. (Christ, I never realized how much like Light he actually is.)

________________________________________________________________

Hey guys! Thanks so so much for reading! I genuinely loved making this theory and I hope that you liked it too. I never really liked making theories about Marvel movies, mostly because I was always dead wrong, but also because I really didn’t want them to disappoint me. Like, when I make a theory about them, I bring my expectations into the theater with me to watch the movie and feel like it’s not as good as what I was expecting, you know? But this is sort of the best of both worlds. Anyways, I really enjoyed making this for you guys and as always, I hope you have a wonderful week.

Hello all my fellow Fan Theorists! Apologies for that major spoiler there. If that hadn’t cued you in, though, this whole post is gonna be riddled with spoilers for Endgame and, yes, Infinity War, too, so if you haven’t seen them, duck out of this post now. (Just a really quick tid-bit: do y’all remember when we thought that everyone who died was in the soul world? Oops.)

So, let’s talk about Infinity War and Endgame, the unofficial two part Avengers movie, both of which were equally devastating, maybe even more so for Endgame because Tony isn’t coming back, at least not as RDJ. With that gut punch out of the way, let’s get into it. Infinity War and Endgame both have very different feels from one another, as if they’d both been directed by two different people. From what I’ve seen of the Russos’ work, in this franchise at least, they tend to have that serious, realistic vibe to their movies in a way that DC comics utterly fails with theirs. I mean, Civil War, while not being my favorite movie in the franchise, was a really fantastic movie and did the “gritty realism” tone very well. They also produced one of the most well-loved Marvel movies of all time, Captain America: The Winter Soldier, which genuinely made Marvel movies what we know they are today. And in that vein, I think that Infinity War feels a lot like those movies, but Endgame? Nope. It has a dark, depressing tone about it, as if the whole thing, beginning to end, is just one long funeral, and I think that was the point, cause it kinda was. I mean, half of the characters, including the most beloved Marvel character of all time (Spidey), were dead, including fan favorites, like Black Panther, Loki, and all of the Guardians.

But probably the biggest difference between the two was Thanos. He felt like a genuinely different person. Gone was the somewhat sympathetic, yet still very evil deflated plum, replaced by an egotistical psychopath with a god complex. And the differences aren’t even subtle. So what happened? Well, the reason that I think Infinity War and Endgame are so different was because the two of them were set through two different perspectives. In Endgame, it was pretty clear that Tony was the protagonist, but in Infinity War, it isn’t very clear. The plot is scattered throughout three different big settings, on Titan, in Wakanda, and on Vormir, each scene having a different tone and feel to them. For example, Titan had a “sunset” vibe, as if the sun was setting on everyone’s time there on Titan, indicating that, no, they would not win there. Wakanda had a “new day” sort of vibe, and seeing as it was the last stop on Thanos’ list, we figured that it would be the location that the Avengers would win the battle, and if they weren’t planning on pulling the rug out from under us, we’d have been right. And Vormir is special because it has this magical, mystical vibe, as if it is taking place within Twilight, which makes sense since it is a magical, mystical place. And despite all of that, there is still one constant in the plot, one character that connects everything together: Thanos. *cue the gasps*

Yes, you heard me correctly, Thanos, the big, ugly grape dude who killed off Peter Parker, is Infinity War’s protagonist. Now, don’t get me wrong here, he’s not the hero, he’s not even a good guy, and protagonist doesn’t have to mean “hero,” it just has be the person around which the story is centered, and the story is unabashedly centered around Thanos. Don’t believe me?

Yeah, remember this? Historically, they have only ever, ever done this for the main protagonist(s) of the film. Iron Man? Iron Man will return. Captain America? Captain America will return. The Avengers? The Avengers will return. Every time without fail they have put the protagonists and only the protagonists in that slot there. So, where does that leave us? Well, it explains why the two movies were so distinctly different. Each major scene’s tone was reflected through his eyes. Vormir? A beautiful and slightly mystical atmosphere with a somber tone, because Gamora is dead but he is collecting the Soul Stone. Titan? The sun setting on the time that half the universe has. Wakanda? A bright, sunny atmosphere where literally nothing could possibly go wrong with his plan and no one can stand in his way. That’s why we get that weird Gamora in the soul stone flash back and why we see him sitting on his farm in the final scene as the sun rises on a new era of his making. It is a beautiful, spectacular movie and I cannot stress that enough, even if the protagonist is a rotten prune and half of the universe dies, and this symbolism is a huge part of why that is.

So now, let’s talk about Endgame Thanos. He is cold, evil, and nothing like his Infinity War self, but honestly, is that a big shock to anyone? I mean, in literally every other movie, he has been an evil, dangerous tyrant, then he shows up in Infinity War as a misunderstood bad boy and everyone just… accepts it? No, no, no, no. What we have here is a case of there-are-two-sides-to-every-story-itis. Thanos is a power-hungry dictator who wants death and destruction and his actions in Infinity War, killing off innocent people and killing anyone who gets in his way, or attempting to, but we just think that it is flawed story telling because we don’t realize that it is all being told from inside of Thanos’ twisted mind. Endgame Thanos is the true Thanos. The gross raisin of death who throws a tantrum when he doesn’t get his way and wants to play with people’s lives like they’re dolls, that is who he really is. (Christ, I never realized how much like Light he actually is.)

________________________________________________________________

Hey guys! Thanks so so much for reading! I genuinely loved making this theory and I hope that you liked it too. I never really liked making theories about Marvel movies, mostly because I was always dead wrong, but also because I really didn’t want them to disappoint me. Like, when I make a theory about them, I bring my expectations into the theater with me to watch the movie and feel like it’s not as good as what I was expecting, you know? But this is sort of the best of both worlds. Anyways, I really enjoyed making this for you guys and as always, I hope you have a wonderful week.
trail.content:
OH GOD SORRY! SPOILER ALERT!

Hello all my fellow Fan Theorists! Apologies for that major spoiler there. If that hadn’t cued you in, though, this whole post is gonna be riddled with spoilers for Endgame and, yes, Infinity War, too, so if you haven’t seen them, duck out of this post now. Well, it explains why the two movies were so distinctly different. Each major scene’s tone was reflected through his eyes. Vormir? A beautiful and slightly mystical atmosphere with a somber tone, because Gamora is dead but he is collecting the Soul Stone. Titan? The sun setting on the time that half the universe has. Wakanda? A bright, sunny atmosphere where literally nothing could possibly go wrong with his plan and no one can stand in his way. So now, let’s talk about Endgame Thanos. He is cold, evil, and nothing like his Infinity War self, but honestly, is that a big shock to anyone? What we have here is a case of there-are-two-sides-to-every-story-itis. Thanos is a power-hungry dictator who wants death and destruction and his actions in Infinity War, killing off innocent people and killing anyone who gets in his way, or attempting to, but we just think that it is flawed story telling because we don’t realize that it is all being told from inside of Thanos’ twisted mind. Endgame Thanos is the true Thanos. The gross raisin of death who throws a tantrum when he doesn’t get his way and wants to play with people’s lives like they’re dolls, that is who he really is. (Christ, I never realized how much like Light he actually is.)

________________________________________________________________

Hey guys! Thanks so so much for reading! I genuinely loved making this theory and I hope that you liked it too. I never really liked making theories about Marvel movies, mostly because I was always dead wrong, but also because I really didn’t want them to disappoint me. Like, when I make a theory about them, I bring my expectations into the theater with me to watch the movie and feel like it’s not as good as what I was expecting, you know? But this is sort of the best of both worlds. Anyways, I really enjoyed making this for you guys and as always, I hope you have a wonderful week.

summary: Home Entertainment Quarterly Trailer Reminds Us Whats Coming To Home Release Soon
title: Home Entertainment Quarterly Trailer Reminds Us Whats Coming To Home Release Soon
body:
Home Entertainment Quarterly Trailer Reminds Us Whats Coming To Home Release Soon

We love films, we love television as well and some may think we are bombarded film requests to review. We would love to review everything but it’s virtually impossible on all platforms (cinema, Home release, TV, Streaming, etc…).

British Association for Screen Entertainment aka BASE are trying to help on the home front. Every Quarter of the year we get the Home Entertainment Quarterly Trailer.…

View On WordPress

title: Mtv Movie & Tv Awards - Avengers: Endgame e Il Trono di Spade tra i vincitori
body:
Mtv Movie & Tv Awards – Avengers: Endgame e Il Trono di Spade tra i vincitori

Nella notte italiana sono stati assegnati gli Mtv Movie & Tv Awards, gli ambiti premi assegnati dallo storico network al meglio di cinema e tv della scorsa stagione.

A dominare la categoria cinematografica, e non poteva essere altrimenti, è stato Avengers: Endgame. Il kolossal Marvel ha vinto il premio Miglior Film, ma anche altri premi, tra cui Miglior Combattimento (Marvel vs Minn-Erva),…

summary:
Thinking about some fix-it’s where (a) Natasha survives Endgame...
Honestly, when Steve brings the Soul Stone back, he could...
body:
Thinking about some fix-it’s where (a) Natasha survives Endgame…

Honestly, when Steve brings the Soul Stone back, he could give it to Natasha and Clint before she jumps. That’s how simple it is. The. There’s an alt timeline where everything happens the same way, except Natasha lives, and we could follow that timeline.

Or if he’s worried about messing up another timeline, like if Nat just isn’t supposed to be in the battle for whatever reason… tell Clint to tell the others she died, to really say it, and then that Nat can just return to 2023 but only after the battle or secretly like old man Rogers.

Like for all the talk of it being irreversible, there’s still logical and easy ways to bring her back if Marvel decided to. If her solo was really successful, and they wanted to tell more stories with her.

These would all be alt timelines, of course… we saw Nat die in Endgame, Clint saw her die, he wasn’t lying about anything and he was genuinely mourning her… but these would be near identical timelines with her survival being the only difference. 🤷‍♂️

Like for all the talk of it being irreversible, there’s still logical and easy ways to bring her back if Marvel decided to. If her solo was really successful, and they wanted to tell more stories with her.

Like for all the talk of it being irreversible, there’s still logical and easy ways to bring her back if Marvel decided to. If her solo was really successful, and they wanted to tell more stories with her.

Thinking about some fix-it’s where (a) Natasha survives Endgame…

Honestly, when Steve brings the Soul Stone back, he could give it to Natasha and Clint before she jumps. That’s how simple it is. The. There’s an alt timeline where everything happens the same way, except Natasha lives, and we could follow that timeline.

Or if he’s worried about messing up another timeline, like if Nat just isn’t supposed to be in the battle for whatever reason… tell Clint to tell the others she died, to really say it, and then that Nat can just return to 2023 but only after the battle or secretly like old man Rogers.
